citations.narrative:
At the time of the inspection, there were no copies of the medical records generated from the annual head-to-tail physical
examinations of seven wolf hybrids performed by the attending veterinarian in August 2024. Adequate records are
necessary to ensure the health of the animals and to ensure that the guidance of the attending veterinarian is being
followed.
Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available
for APHIS inspection. These records must (in part) include: the identity of the animal, including identifying marks, tattoos,
or tags on the animal and the animal’s breed, sex, and age; Provided, however, that routine husbandry, such as
vaccinations, preventive medical procedures, or treatments, performed on all animals in a group, may be kept on a single
record. See 2, 3, and 4 in the AWA regulations for additional requirements of medical records for dogs and dog hybrids.
Correct by August 28, 2025, and forward.

At the time of inspection, five rabbits were in the same enclosure as two cavies. Housing rabbits with other species could
negatively impact their health and well-being as they are a prey species and are susceptible to many microorganisms.
Rabbits shall not be housed in the same primary enclosure with any other species of animals unless required for scientific
reasons.
Corrected on the day of inspection Sept. 11, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.13(b)(1) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
At the time of the inspection, there were no copies of the medical records generated from the annual head-to-tail physical 
examinations of seven wolf hybrids performed by the attending veterinarian in August 2024. Adequate records are 
necessary to ensure the health of the animals and to ensure that the guidance of the attending veterinarian is being 
followed.  
 
Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available 
for APHIS inspection. These records must (in part) include: the identity of the animal, including identifying marks, tattoos, 
or tags on the animal and the animal’s breed, sex, and age; Provided, however, that routine husbandry, such as 
vaccinations, preventive medical procedures, or treatments, performed on all animals in a group, may be kept on a single 
record. See 2, 3, and 4 in the AWA regulations for additional requirements of medical records for dogs and dog hybrids. 
 
Correct by August 28, 2025, and forward. 
3.58(a) 
   
Classification and separation. 
At the time of inspection, five rabbits were in the same enclosure as two cavies. Housing rabbits with other species could 
negatively impact their health and well-being as they are a prey species and are susceptible to many microorganisms. 
 
Rabbits shall not be housed in the same primary enclosure with any other species of animals unless required for scientific 
reasons. 
 
Corrected on the day of inspection Sept. 11, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
